alert.note: Alert for Baldwin Peninsula; Bering Strait Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Interior Seward Peninsula; Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Lower Koyukuk Valley; Lower Yukon River; Lower Yukon and Innoko Valleys; Middle Yukon Valley; Noatak Valley; North Slopes of the Western Alaska Range; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref; South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; St Lawrence Island; Upper Kobuk Valleys; Upper Kuskokwim Valley; Yukon Delta Coast (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 10 at 4:33AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks
info.description: ...Two Impactful Winter Storms Sunday Through Thursday... Two consecutive winter storms are expected to impact the West Coast and Western Interior starting on Sunday and could bring a combination of winter impacts including heavy snow, strong winds, and the potential for elevated water levels with storm surge along the coast. The first storm will reach the West Coast on Sunday with heavy snow, south, southeast, and southwest winds gusting as high as 55 mph, and snow possibly changing to rain late Sunday before turning back to wet snow. Locations north and east of Norton Sound coastline will remain all snow. In addition, elevated water levels are likely along the coast, especially over Norton Sound and the YK Delta, where water levels of 4 to 7 feet above the normal high tide are projected Monday into Monday night as the front moves inland. A second storm will impact the region beginning late Tuesday through Thursday. This system will bring the possibility of heavy snow and strong, gusty winds. The heaviest snowfall looks to be over the Lower Yukon Valley and Kuskokwim Valley to Alaska Range. There is still some uncertainty with details with the second storm, and residents should stay alert for additional updates to the forecast and prepare for stormy weather late this weekend into next week.
